ReACT_title: Document the code structure: Clearly document the way that the code is organized, and how the components, modules, classes, packages relate to each other. A thorough documentation about the structure and relationship among its modules can make it easier for the new developers to understand the code and find the artifacts they need.

articles.title: Why we engage in FLOSS: answers from core developers
articles.details: In Proceedings of the 11th International Workshop on Cooperative and Human Aspects of Software Engineering (CHASE '18). Association for Computing Machinery, New York, NY, USA, 114–121.

ReACT_title: Promote code transparency/ Keep the code as simple as possible: Code is supposed to be read by humans. Refactor the code constantly to make it more readable. The source code is the set of artifacts that need to be understood and changed by the members to contribute. Sometimes it is not easy to make it simple because the core of a large application is inherently complex, and the code reflects this complexity. However, directing newcomers to peripheral modules (at least warning them of the complexity) would benefit newcomers during their first steps.

articles.title: Difficulties of Newcomers Joining Software Projects Already in Execution

ReACT_title: Be quick to respond to the newcomer: Remember that participants are people who chose to spend time trying to help. Do not let their motivation decrease. Do not make the newcomers wait or leave them unanswered. Automatic greetings could help, at least to send the message that someone will answer them quickly, or to guide them to another possible communication channel.

articles.title: Fostering Free/Libre Open Source Software community formation: guidelines for communities to support newcomers’ onboarding
Joining free/open source software communities: An analysis of newbies' first interactions on project mailing lists

ReACT_title: Be kind and make newcomers feel part of the team: Experienced members should answer newcomers’ messages and welcome them, even if they have already received an answer. Designating a few experienced members to deal with new members, or setting a code of conduct can potentially solve reception issues. Send thankful, welcoming messages to account for cultural differences and misunderstandings.

Keep the page clean, organized, up-todate, and easy to follow.

articles.title: Fostering Free/Libre Open Source Software community formation: guidelines for communities to support newcomers’ onboarding
Let me in: Guidelines for the successful onboarding of newcomers to open source projects

ReACT_title: Set expectations and needs early:  Show newcomers what is expected from them, where the difficulties lie, and what skills and level of expertise they need to have (what programming languages and technologies are used by the project, etc.). Place this information somewhere that newcomers access early in their journey
Entity_responsible: Project Leaders, Collaboration Coordinators, Community Managers

articles.title: Fostering Free/Libre Open Source Software community formation: guidelines for communities to support newcomers’ onboarding
Let me in: Guidelines for the successful onboarding of newcomers to open source projects

ReACT_title: Show the path, the easiest path: Create an easy to access, easy to follow path on which newcomers can start their journey. Leave breadcrumbs, left intentionally for them, to guide the newcomers to easy tasks.

articles.title: Fostering Free/Libre Open Source Software community formation: guidelines for communities to support newcomers’ onboarding
Let me in: Guidelines for the successful onboarding of newcomers to open source projects

ReACT_title: Create different kinds of tutorials and documents: Provide videos, demos, screenshots, and step-by-step tutorials for the different contribution phases. Make these tutorials simple and clear, especially for more complicated activities.
Entity_responsible: Documentation Team, Design Team, Technical Leads

articles.title: Fostering Free/Libre Open Source Software community formation: guidelines for communities to support newcomers’ onboarding
Let me in: Guidelines for the successful onboarding of newcomers to open source projects

ReACT_title: Make it easy for newcomers build the system locally: Create a step-by-step detailed tutorial, which is linked to information about usual problems and possible solutions (an excerpt of FAQ section)
Entity_responsible: Documentation Team, Technical Leads, Collaboration Coordinators

articles.title: Fostering Free/Libre Open Source Software community formation: guidelines for communities to support newcomers’ onboarding
Let me in: Guidelines for the successful onboarding of newcomers to open source projects

ReACT_title: Keep the issue list clean and triaged: Read the issue list frequently in order to clean outdated tasks and triage/tag issues. Outdated, comment-less issues can be scary to newcomers.
Entity_responsible: Code Reviewers, Project Maintainers, Collaboration Coordinators

articles.title: Fostering Free/Libre Open Source Software community formation: guidelines for communities to support newcomers’ onboarding
Let me in: Guidelines for the successful onboarding of newcomers to open source projects

ReACT_title: Document the processes and practices: Document all design decisions, processes and practices defined and make them easily accessible. Information like code/naming standards, patch submission process, task assignment process, communication practices, design decisions etc. need to be properly documented, helping newcomers in their first contributions. Remember to present the technical and social processes and practices.
Entity_responsible: Documentation Team, Project Leaders, Technical Leads

articles.title: Fostering Free/Libre Open Source Software community formation: guidelines for communities to support newcomers’ onboarding
Let me in: Guidelines for the successful onboarding of newcomers to open source projects

ReACT_title: Dismiss or identify outdated information:  if it is hard to keep documentation up-to-date, community members should remove outdated information or, at least, clearly identify it as outdated. Making newcomers aware of the absence or the status of a document can save their time and set their expectations.
Entity_responsible: Documentation Team, Community Moderators, Collaboration Coordinators

articles.title: Fostering Free/Libre Open Source Software community formation: guidelines for communities to support newcomers’ onboarding
Let me in: Guidelines for the successful onboarding of newcomers to open source projects

ReACT_title: Create a live FAQ section. Create FAQ sections to help developers finding answer to recurrent questions. The FAQ must not be a static section; it must be live and grow according to questions and issues recurrently asked or reported. The community can build the FAQ cooperatively, in a wiki-like page, enabling anyone to contribute with entries (question + answer).
Entity_responsible: Documentation Team, Collaboration Coordinators, Community Moderators

articles.title: Fostering Free/Libre Open Source Software community formation: guidelines for communities to support newcomers’ onboarding
Let me in: Guidelines for the successful onboarding of newcomers to open source projects

ReACT_title: Keep the community informed about decisions. When a developer choose a task to work on, they should add a comment to the issue stating that they are trying to address it. In the same way, developer should inform the community if they give up or find any problem related to the task, keeping the task updated.This way, they avoid reproducing the work of other developers
